image.altText: A child sits in a front passenger seat using a phone with the seatbelt over their head

items.synopsis: Transport Minister Mark Bailey said the department is seeking "urgent legal advice on the swift re-issuance of incorrectly suspended licences".

title.children: 'This is our mistake': Transport department issues hundreds of 'incorrect' seatbelt penalties

image.altText: A man with a moustache in front of a party tent.

items.synopsis: Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden, accused of killing his stepfather Robert Lumsden last month, will be suspended from his role in local government on full pay until the next election in March 2024.

title.children: Gold Coast councillor charged with stepfather's murder accepts voluntary suspension

image.altText: A woman sitting in her seat in the House of Representatives

items.synopsis: North Sydney independent MP Kylea Tink says an opposition member yelled at her aggressively in parliament on Wednesday, but Mr Dutton says he has no concerns with the account he's been given.

title.children: Peter Dutton has 'no concerns' about 'aggressive' behaviour of opposition MP

image.altText: A woman faces side on while wearing a crown and a royal cape.

items.synopsis: The King acknowledged the anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II's death in a short statement shared on social media.

title.children: 'Recall with great affection': Charles marks first anniversary of late queen

image.altText: Kobie Parfitt looks directly at the camera. She has long brown hair and is wearing a black top.

items.synopsis: Shannon Jeffrey, 34, had fatally assaulted Kobie Parfitt, 42, and dumped her body down a mineshaft. The crime went undetected for eight months. Today, she has been sentenced for manslaughter.

title.children: Woman jailed for killing Ballarat mother of four and dumping her body down a mineshaft

image.altText: Townsville Mayor Jenny Hill stands near emergency services vehicles.

items.synopsis: Katter's Australia Party is proposing to send repeat youth offenders between 10 and 17 years old to a 12-month outback camp for rehabilitation, and it has the backing of several north Queensland mayors.

title.children: Townsville mayor supports plan to banish child criminals to 'intense' outback rehabilitation camps

image.altText: Smoke from a bushfire in the distance

items.synopsis: Residents near Cecil Plains warned to be prepared to leave as RFS worries about erratic bushfire behaviour with a forecast change in the weather today.

title.children: Weather plagues firefighters as southern Queensland blaze triples in size in a day

image.altText: Sgt Richard Monei sits at table with police hat next to him

items.synopsis: Richard Monaei joined the Queensland Police Service when he was 18. He's now an advocate so other First Nations people don't suffer as he did.

title.children: Racism forced Richard out of Queensland Police. He says a newly announced review is 'long overdue'

image.altText: Payne wearing a red jacket and dark-rimmed glasses looks across frame.

items.synopsis: One of the Liberal Party's most senior women, and the first woman to hold the defence portfolio in Australia, will retire from politics after 26 years in parliament.

title.children: 'A grand contribution': Former minister and Liberal stalwart Marise Payne to quit politics

image.altText: Gerard Rennick sits on the backbench in the Senate looking into the distance

items.synopsis: Coalition senator Gerard Rennick has questioned the basis for claims Australia's Indigenous history dates back more than 60,000 years. What do the experts say?

title.children: What's the evidence for 60,000 years of Indigenous history?

image.altText: A man with short dark hair pictured with his daughter whose face is pixellated

items.synopsis: The tight-knit WA community of Kellerberrin faces a long road to recovery after a father was shot dead by another well-known local resident, sparking a manhunt and police stand-off that forced the town into lockdown.

title.children: Father Terry Czernowski officially identified as victim of WA workplace fatal shooting

image.altText: A black and white photo with about 100 people standing in front of an old country pub.

items.synopsis: They were once thriving communities with their own pubs, schools, and railway networks, but as bust followed boom hundreds of small mining towns in far north Queensland were abandoned or demolished as people sought fortunes elsewhere.

title.children: Deserted and forgotten, these boom-and-bust mining towns were once measured by their number of pubs

image.altText: A tree-lined horizon, with a helicopter highlight by a red circle.

items.synopsis: The South Australian government is investigating its own safety protocols after a distressed deer hunter filmed himself trying to take shelter from a culling helicopter that appeared to be firing nearby.

title.children: 'We're gonna get shot': Hunters film themselves running from aerial culling helicopter on SA property

image.altText: A man with a jacket over his head

items.synopsis: Christopher Borg pleaded guilty to two counts of common assault and failed to have the charges dismissed on the grounds of mental health issues.

title.children: Ex-NSW police officer has sentence cut for 'entirely unprovoked' kicking of Indigenous teen

image.altText: A man walks along a road with a jacket over his shoulders and head.

items.synopsis: Greece has been slammed by "extraordinary" downpours from a weather pattern shaped like the final letter of the country's alphabet. Here is why this one was so intense.

title.children: Parts of Greece have recorded an entire year's worth of rain in 18 hours, a month after heatwaves and fire. What's caused it?

image.altText: A man in a white shirt looks into a food delivery bag

items.synopsis: An analysis of data from China's second largest food delivery service shows that adding a "green nudge" could eliminate more than 3 million tonnes of single-use plastic.

title.children: A simple 'green nudge' could save millions of tonnes of plastic waste each year

image.altText: An image from That '70s Show of a man with curly hair and glasses smiling, next to a photo of a man in a courtroom in a suit

items.synopsis: The star of That '70s Show is facing life in prison for raping two women, in a case which has stirred controversy around the church where he and his victims met.

title.children: 'Your sickness is no longer mine to bear': The key moments from Danny Masterson's sentencing

image.altText: Vivienne Mitchell's face and upper body is superimposed over a picture of razors that has a price tag of $43

items.synopsis: Backlash against Coles and Woolworths is swirling on social media as the supermarket giants record large profits amid a cost of living crisis. But one expert says the anger, and calls for a boycott, are unlikely to have a lasting effect.

title.children: How one Australian's 'sheer disbelief' at the rising cost of groceries reached 1.7 million shoppers

image.altText: a man ina lab coat leaning on a large furnace

items.synopsis: A furnace that reaches 3,000 degrees Celsius is helping scientists make parts for hypersonic jets and test components for space travel and defence.

title.children: This furnace is the hottest in the southern hemisphere, and it's used to make hypersonic jets

image.altText: An outdoor tap drips with water.

items.synopsis: Long-term modelling shows water grid storage levels could drop to the trigger point for restrictions by the end of next year.

title.children: Dam modelling shows Brisbane region could face water restrictions next year if dry conditions continue

image.altText: A protester being taken away by police at the US Open.

items.synopsis: The match is delayed for almost 50 minutes following a disruption by environmental activists inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, before Coco Gauff goes on to beat Karolína Muchová in straight sets to reach her first US Open final.

title.children: Environmental activist glues his feet to the ground as protest interrupts US Open semifinal

image.altText: A selfie of a serious man with shaved hair next to his large brown dog.

items.synopsis: Surfer Tony Begg is lucky to be alive after being attacked by a shark on a NSW beach. The off-duty doctor who saved him says he is a "fighter".

title.children: It's 'absolutely crazy' he survived, says responding off-duty doctor after shark attack

image.altText: People cross the road at an intersection in a busy CBD.

items.synopsis: The corporate regulator is suing Australia's largest superannuation fund for allegedly failing to address multiple superannuation accounts belonging to 90,000 customers, while the ASX is lower after a flat start. Follow live.

title.children: ASIC sues AustralianSuper over 'failure' that took $69m from the accounts of 90,000 members, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Chevron spokesperson has just provided a statement in response to Chevron workers walking off the job this afternoon as their industrial dispute continues. "We have been advised by the unions that protected industrial action will not take place at our facilities until 1.00pm AWST Friday 8 September. "We will continue to work through the bargaining process as we seek outcomes that are in the interests of both employees and the company. "We will also continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption at our facilities."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron responds to strike action to be taken by workers

children.content: A Chevron spokesperson has just provided a statement in response to Chevron workers walking off the job this afternoon as their industrial dispute continues.
"We have been advised by the unions that protected industrial action will not take place at our facilities
until 1.00pm AWST
Friday 8 September.
"We will
continue to work through the bargaining process
as we seek outcomes that are in the interests of both employees and the company.
"We will also continue to take steps to
maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption
at our facilities."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate regulator's deputy chair, Sarah Court, spoke to senior business correspondent Peter Ryan about ASIC's legal action against AustralianSuper over its duplicate account failures. She told The World Today the fact the conduct occurred for 10 years was concerning. "What we're concerned [with] here, we've got the largest superfund in the country," she said. "This conduct went for a period of about 10 years, 90,000 members affected and $69 million is being remediated. "These obligations have been in place since 2013. And yes, we at ASIC have been calling on the superannuation industry to make sure that they do have the right processes and systems in place to meet these obligations." But Ms Court declined to say how big a penalty ASIC was seeking over the issue, but expects it to be substantial. "It's an early stage ... I think, suffice to say, there is the potential for very significant penalties to be imposed in relation to this conduct," she said. "But that is down the track and we will wait and see where we get to in the court proceedings."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC says 'very significant penalties' could be imposed on AustralianSuper

children.content: The corporate regulator's deputy chair,
Sarah Court
, spoke to
senior business correspondent Peter Ryan
about ASIC's legal action against
AustralianSuper
over its duplicate account failures.
She told
The World Today
the fact the conduct occurred for 10 years was concerning.
"What we're concerned [with] here, we've got the largest superfund in the country," she said.
"This
conduct went for a period of about 10 years, 90,000 members affected and $69 million is being remediated

"These obligations have been in place since 2013. And yes, we at ASIC have been calling on the superannuation industry to make sure that they do have the right processes and systems in place to meet these obligations."
But Ms Court declined to say how big a penalty ASIC was seeking over the issue, but expects it to be substantial.
"It's an early stage ... I think, suffice to say,
there is the potential for very significant penalties to be imposed
in relation to this conduct," she said.
"But that is down the track and
we will wait and see
where we get to in the court proceedings."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This graph tells a stark story. New data from the ABS today shows the number of people with two or more jobs has hit another record-high. But it also shows how growth in multiple job-holders is continuing to outpace growth in employed persons. The number of people holding multiple jobs hit 959,000 in the June quarter 2023. That's an increase of 7 per cent over the past year. Bjorn Jarvis, ABS head of labour statistics, said: “Around one in 15 people had more than one job in the June quarter 2023, compared to one in 18 people 20 years ago.” “Looking over the past 20 years, there are around 50 per cent more employed people than there were in June quarter 2003, but close to 80 per cent more multiple job-holders.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Multiple job holding hits another record

children.content: This graph tells a stark story.
New data from the ABS today shows
the number of people with two or more jobs
has hit another record-high.
But it also shows how
growth in multiple job-holders is continuing to outpace growth in employed persons
The number of people holding multiple jobs hit
in the June quarter 2023.
That's an increase of 7 per cent over the past year.
Bjorn Jarvis, ABS head of labour statistics, said: “Around one in 15 people had more than one job in the June quarter 2023, compared to one in 18 people 20 years ago.”
“Looking over the past 20 years, there are around 50 per cent more employed people than there were in June quarter 2003, but close to 80 per cent more multiple job-holders.”

image.altText: A large cloud of smoke from a bushfire rising into the sky, over a major highway at sunset.

items.synopsis: Authorities are forecasting hotter, drier and windier conditions across Central Australia that will heighten the risk of catastrophic bushfires over summer.

title.children: Entire NT declared fire danger area until March as 'enormous' blaze closes highway

image.altText: A close up of Meghan Markle smiling and waving at the camera, walking through a crowd of people

items.synopsis: The men in their 60s plead guilty over the messages, which also featured references to Britain's first prime minister of colour, Rishi Sunak.

title.children: Former UK police behind 'absolutely appalling' racist messages about Meghan Markle

image.altText: An Australian player looks to her left before a match at the Women's T20 World Cup in 2023.

items.synopsis: Cricket Australia confirms captain Meg Lanning will not play in the upcoming T20 and ODI series against West Indies, with Alyssa Healy to lead the world champions.

title.children: Lanning to miss Australia's series against West Indies, Healy named skipper

image.altText: Queen Elizabeth stands smiling and leaning on a cane next to a lit fireplace.

items.synopsis: The plans for her death were meticulous. Her lavish funeral had a code name. But when the kingdom's second Elizabethan era drew to a close, everyone suddenly seemed to be a little caught off-guard.

title.children: The inside story of the Queen's final hours, and how they foretold the first year of Charles's reign

image.altText: Close up of Catherine King

items.synopsis: Transport Minister Catherine King has pledged airfares will soon come down, saying Qatar Airways is "not the only airline that adds to competition".

title.children: Catherine King says airfares 'will come down' as other airlines increase capacity

image.altText: Hundreds of pelicans are seen across an inland lake.

items.synopsis: A group of scientists finds despite billions of dollars spent on the Murray Darling Basin Plan, many of the indicators used to measure whether the environment is receiving enough water have been getting worse.

title.children: First pelican breeding frenzy at lake since 1999 sustained by buying water from farmers, scientists say

image.altText: Man in red jacket with light on his head

items.synopsis: The operation to rescue the experienced US cave researcher from the depths of southern Türkiye's Taurus Mountains involves teams from Bulgaria, Croatia, Hungary, Italy, Poland and Türkiye.

title.children: Race to save injured explorer 1,000 metres inside cave in Türkiye

image.altText: Brahman cattle at Anna Plains Station, July 2022.

items.synopsis: While no formal agreement has been reached, the government says recent discussions have been positive, after the prime minister raised the matter with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo.

title.children: Indonesia poised to resume live cattle imports from Australia

image.altText: Naomi Bowden

items.synopsis: Through tears Naomi Bowden tells a NSW inquiry into birth trauma how distressing it was to have police take her stillborn daughter and put her in an ice box in front of her.

title.children: Naomi speaks up about the 'disrespectful' treatment she received after her baby was stillborn

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek and fish farming pens in Macquarie Harbour, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: Federal environmental minister Tanya Plibersek has been told by her department that farmed salmon in Macquarie Harbour must be rapidly reduced by this summer to help prevent the extinction of the Maugean skate.

title.children: Destock salmon farms or face first human-induced ray extinction, minister told

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Scott Morrison

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Scott Morrison has warned that his successor should not be "too keen" to accept an invitation to China, as Anthony Albanese prepares to visit Beijing within months.

title.children: Scott Morrison says Anthony Albanese shouldn't rush to visit Beijing this year

image.altText: A satellite image showing Australia, New Zealand and an enormous mushroom cloud from a volcanic eruption in the Pacific ocean

items.synopsis: In January 2022, a mega explosion from the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano generated a coast-battering tsunami and vivid sunsets. Now we know the extent of the eruption's devastation below the waves.

title.children: We knew the Tongan volcanic eruption was massive. Now we know what happened on the sea floor
